learning_outcomes.description: Develop a broad understanding of contemporary Korean society through the social, cultural and political issues represented in contemporary films.
Identify relevant sources and use them in developing original interpretation of the topic.
Critically analyse multi-modal resources in the social and historical contexts
Understand how South Korean media have served as a cultural medium to reflect ideologies in society and apply their knowledge in the critical review in the forms of writing and speaking.

assessments.category: Computer Code, Essay/ Critique, Participation/ Student contribution, Reflection
assessments.task_description:
Students are expected to study each week's topic by attending the Monday lecture, reading from the course reading list and writing a reflection before coming to Thursday class in which class discussion will be made based on the students' reflections. In the Weekly Reflection, the media content or online discourse surrounding the content needs to be reviewed.

Students should insert a link to the resource or add a copy of the resource on the course Padlet and write a 150-word reflection about the resource. The reflection must (1) summarise what the resource is about, and (2) explain how it is relevant to the topic. Students may extend their reflection to the application of such a topic in their culture; e.g. 'this may be compared to that of my culture, because...'.

The link to the course Padlet will be provided in the course's Blackboard. Each week's reflection will be due at 5 pm Wednesday, the day before Thursday class, every week between Week 3 and Week 12.

Weekly Reflection does not require students to read further references but asks students to explore various discourses in media around given topics and critically think about different approaches and interpretations made onto the same topic.

Any assignment found copied from sources on the internet or other students' work will receive 0 point and be referred to the Integrity Officer.

AI and MT STATEMENT

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of the assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission, independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submissions should be made through the course Padlet for each week's topic.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
14/08/2025 - 23/10/2025

Presentation to be delivered in class in the week selected by the student (WEEK 3 - WEEK 12).
assessments.category: Essay/ Critique, Participation/ Student contribution, Presentation, Reflection
assessments.task_description:
Students will conduct a critical review of a topic chosen among those covered in the course. In Week 1, a sign-up sheet for choosing a week for their presentation will be shared on Blackboard.

 The critical review comprises:

(1) three resources (media content or related discourses) in different forms that discuss the chosen topic, e.g. news articles, YouTube clips (and/or the comments), blog posts, academic journal articles, books, films, TV shows, twitter mentions, podcast clips, etc., including a resource designated by the instructor, 

(2) reflections of the three resources in 150+ words each (450+ words in total), and

(3) oral presentation of their critical review of the topic using the three media/discourses in 10 - 15 minutes.

The critical review may develop from the topic's historical/social context and experts' critiques on the topic to comparison to media discourses in other culture or society. It should have at least two references from the course's reading list in addition to the three resources chosen for review presentation. The presentation may include video or audio playing where necessary for discussion (excluded from the presentation time). Presenters are asked to take the initiative to lead a class discussion and respond appropriately to questions from the class. 

The links to or copies of the three resources and their reflections must be submitted to the course's Padlet as their usual Weekly Review. The critical review should have a reference list including the two references from the course's reading list and the three media resources. The oral presentation needs to be summarised in 800 words (+/- 10%; excluding reference list) and submitted through Turnitin by 5 pm Wednesday in the week of their presentation. 

AI and MT STATEMENT

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Presentation summary needs to be submitted via Turnitin. Oral presentation delivered during class of selected week.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
14/08/2025 - 23/10/2025

Discussion reports are due on MONDAY of the week following the week of the discussion participation (WEEK 3 to WEEK 12).
assessments.category: Essay/ Critique, Participation/ Student contribution, Reflection
assessments.task_description:
Students will be asked to participate in in-class discussions for three topics they choose. After the week's critical review presentations are finished, the 'discussant' students should (1) share their studied resources, which they submitted as Weekly Reflection, (2) add comments to the week's presentation(s), and (3) ask a relevant and intriguing question to each presenter. 

For the three weeks chosen for discussion participation, the discussant students will be marked on their in-class discussion participation as well as on a report to be submitted through Turnitin by Monday of the week following the week of their discussion participation. The report needs to be in 300+ words, reflecting what was presented by the presenter and discussed by the discussants in class. 

AI and MT STATEMENT

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Discussion reports should be submitted through Turnitin.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
For the Final Essay assignment, students will be asked to choose one question from a list of several essay prompts and write a 2,000-word (+/-10%) essay. Possible topics for the essay will be discussed in class, and the Final Essay topics will be released in Week 13 on Blackboard. Students should submit their essay via Turnitin by the due date.

Essay Requirements:

Students will write a critical analysis essay on social and/or cultural phenomena of Korea. Your essay must effectively utilise primary course resources (films or books), class discussions, and relevant social media discourse related to your chosen topic. You are expected to demonstrate engagement with course content by incorporating lecture materials, course readings, and insights from class discussions into your analysis.

To develop your argument, draw from weekly reflections, in-depth analysis presentations, and in-class discussions covered throughout the semester. Your essay should manifest your understanding of class discussions by effectively referencing sources while offering your own thoughtful interpretations and critical reflections.

Source Requirements:

  • A minimum of three (3) references from the course reading list must be cited in the essay.
  • Integration of relevant lecture materials and class discussion points is mandatory.
  • Students are encouraged to reference media content or cultural phenomena discussed in class to support their arguments.

Citation and Formatting: Clear citations of all sources (including social media content) using APA referencing style are essential. This includes proper in-text citations and a complete reference list. You are not expected to cite lecture slides.

Submission: Essays must be submitted through Turnitin by the specified due date.

AI and MT STATEMENT

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A coversheet acknowledging the use of AI will be mandatory to be attached. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit your Final Essay via Turnitin on the course Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Introduction to course

Lecture: Overview of the course

Tutorial: Screening of "Ode to my father"; Discussion on the familism and modern history of South Korea; Critical review of social media discourse on the topic

Learning outcomes: L02, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Familism in "Ode to My Father" and "Mother"

Lecture: Discussion on familism

Tutorial: Social discourse about 'mother' and 'father' in Korean literature, TV drama and film; Critical review of social media discourse on the topic

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Multiculturalism in "Itaewon Class" and "Punch"

Lecture: Discussion on the multiculturalism in Korea and outside Korea

Tutorial: "Itaewon Class", "Minari", "Punch" and "Extraordinary Attorney Woo" in the context of multiculturalism; Critical review of social media discourse on the topic

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Social inequality in "Parasite" and "Squid Game"

Lecture: Discussion on social inequality in contemporary Korea

Tutorial: The young Koreans' life in "Parasite", "Squid Game" and "The Glory"; Critical review of social media discourse on the topic

learning_activities.topic:
Food and culture in "Crying in H Mart"

Lecture: Discussion on Korean food being part of the Korean Wave as well as a popular theme in Korean media

Tutorial: Koreans identified by Korean food in "Crying in H Mart", "Youn's Kitchen" and Chef Paik's shows ; Critical review of social media discourse on the topic

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Individual and society in "Train to Busan"

Lecture: Discussion on the political understanding of the contemporary Korean society

Tutorial: Individuals fighting for the society in "Train to Busan", "Gwanghae" and "All of Us Are Dead"; Critical review of social media discourse on the topic.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Life in "Along with the Gods"

Lecture: Discussion on cultural, philosophical and religious perspectives about life in the contemporary Korean culture

Tutorial: Common thoughts of Koreans about life reflected in "Along with the Gods", "The Goblin", "Oh My Ghost" and talk shows in the 'fortunetelling and counselling' format; Critical review of social media discourse on the topic * Monday 2 October is a public holiday. There will be a make-up class for the holiday, and the time and room information will be informed one week before the holiday.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
